sect1.title: About Dryad
sect1.para: UNIX machines document everything. Everytime something happens, a log message is created. This is both the worst nightmare and greatest asset to a good network administrator. Important events, from hardware failure to attacks on systems, are noted by the system and recorded. However, there is a two fold problem with this default setup. First, the messages need to get off of the generating device; it doesn't do much good to have notification of hardware failure on a broken harddrive, or information about the comprimising of a system in the hands of the attacker. Secondly, the valuable information needs to be sorted from the noise of regular workings. Dryad aims to provide this by being both a remote log server, and a real time processor of log information.

sect1.title: Intended Audience
sect1.para: This document is aimed at implementors of Dryad installations. While it may be interesting to other people, its primary purpose is to explain how to work with Dryad as a user.
